addresses.description1: King Range National Conservation Area Project Office
addresses.remarks: Office Hours: 10:00 a.m. – 4:00 p.m., PST, seven days a week.

description.availability_grid:
Input the number of group members then select the day you plan on entering.

For keyboard users, use the Shift/Tab keys to navigate the table and the space bar to select a start date, as well as an end date if you plan on staying more than one day.
description.cancellation_policy:
Change Policy

  • The permit is non-transferable.

  • Group size can be reduced or increased prior to printing your permit. Please note that increases in group size will only be accommodated up to the available quota for the permitted entry day for your group.

Cancellation Policy

  • The $6 reservation fee is non-refundable. As a courtesy to other users, please cancel your permit or reduce your group size as needed to free up spots for other hikers.
description.description:
Prior to purchasing a permit, please read all provided information under the above tabs ("Need to Know", "Fees/Cancellations", etc.)  

The Bureau of Land Management's King Range National Conservation Area(NCA) is a spectacular meeting of land and sea, as it's mountains seem to thrust straight out of the surf, a precipitous rise rarely surpassed on the continental U.S. coastline. King Peak, the highest point at 4,088 feet, is only 3-miles from the ocean. The King Range NCA encompasses 68,000 acres along 35 miles of California's dramatic north coast. Here, the landscape was too rugged for highway building, forcing State Highway 1 inland. This remote region of mountains and seascapes is known as California's Lost Coast and is accessible only by a few back roads. It is the Nation's first NCA, designated in 1970. The King Range NCA's Douglas fir-covered peaks attract hikers, hunters, and campers, while the coast beckons to surfers, anglers, beachcombers, and many others. World-class mountain bike trails, and 42,585 acres of coastal wilderness are two of the highlights of this incredibly unique area. 

Visitors planning to camp overnight anywhere in the King Range Wilderness must obtain a Wilderness Permit and will be asked to provide a tentative itinerary; including number of days in the wilderness, entrance trailhead, exit trailhead, and backcountry camp zones. 

To assist in planning an overnight trip into the King Range Wilderness, take time to review the Trip Planning Guide, Tide Safety Guide, Map & Guide and Trail/Road Conditions documents under "Plan Your Visit" section of the BLM King Range website: https://www.blm.gov/programs/national-conservation-lands/california/king-range-national-conservation-area.  

The King Range Wilderness is home to the Lost Coast Trail, a backcountry coastal trail that travels along the beach and coastal bluffs. It's imperative that visitors plan this trip carefully, using the above resources to find important safety information. 

Are you an organized group? A school group? A Boy or Girl Scout Troop? A Meetup group? A hiking organization? A commercial outfitter? A shuttle driver? All organized and commercial groups accessing the King Range Wilderness must obtain a Special Recreation Permit along with a Wilderness Permit from the King Range Project Office. Wilderness permits obtained from Recreation.gov alone are not sufficient for organized and commercial groups. Click here for more information and/or to request a Special Recreation Permit.  

For more information or help planning your itinerary, call the King Range Project Office at (707) 986-5400.
description.driving_directions:
The King Range NCA Project Office is located at: 

768 Shelter Cove Road (Physical address) in Whitethorn, CA.

PO Box 189 (Mailing address)
Whitethorn, California 95589
(707) 986-5400 

Call for current road conditions. Plan extra travel time due to narrow and winding roads. High clearance vehicles are recommended on many roads in the area. 

Find directions and driving times between locations within the King Range NCA.
description.fee_policy:
Reservation Fee  

  • For individuals and family groups, there is currently no recreation fee for a King Range Wilderness Permit. However, there is a non-refundable reservation fee of $6 per permit. 
  • For organized* and commercial groups, both a Special Recreation Permit (SRP) and Wilderness Permit are required. For these groups, there is a use fee of either $6 per person per day or 3% of the trips total gross earnings, with a minimum $115 deposit due with submission of the SRP application. If you have any questions as to your group's status, or to request a SRP application packet, please contact the King Range Project Office at 707-986-5400.  

*Organized groups include, but are not limited to: school groups, outdoor clubs, online meet-up groups, Boy and Girl Scout Troops, or any other organized group, outside of a family unit, that is cost-sharing for the trip.
description.lottery_information: Permits are issued on a first-come, first-serve basis through Recreation.gov. There is no lottery system for King Range Wilderness permits and there are no walk-in permits available at the King Range Project Office.
description.need_to_know_email:
All permittees are responsible for stipulations on your permit. Please read Trip Planning Guide and Tide Safety Guide on the King Range website at: https://www.blm.gov/programs/national-conservation-lands/california/king-range-national-conservation-area.

You may print your permit as early as seven days before your reservation date. The permit must be carried by the permit holder. Please carry permit in outside pocket of backpack for easy access to present to ranger. Once your permit has been printed, you cannot make changes to the permit. 

As of 9/29/21, fire restrictions are still in place and NO CAMPFIRES are allowed anywhere in the King Range including the Lost Coast Trail, upland trails, and developed campgrounds. Fire restrictions will be enforced. 

The permittee must ensure that all trip participants abide by the rules, regulations, and Leave No Trace principles https://lnt.org/why/7-principles/

  •  Bear-Proof Food Storage Required. Each person must use an approved hard-sided bear-resistant storage container. When not present, all food, toiletries, trash, dog food, and other scented items must be secured in container.  
  • Human Waste Disposal: When camping along the beach, bury all human waste in the wet sand below the high tide line. On all other trails dig a 6-8' deep hole at least 200 feet from water, trails, and campsites.  Bury or pack out all toilet paper.  
  • Dogs are allowed, but not recommended unless seasoned hiking dogs due to injuries to paws on sharp, hot rocks. Leashes are required between Punta Gorda and Sea Lion Gulch at all times. 
  • Stay off lower beach from Windy Point to the lighthouse to avoid elephant seals that may be on the trail. 
  • Do not build driftwood structures--leave no trace of you being there! Driftwood structures become perfect homes for rattlesnakes, please beware.
  • Pack out what you pack in. Do not burn trash-pack it out.  
  • Ocean swimming is never recommended due to strong undertow.
  • Have a wonderful adventure!
description.need_to_know_order:
Permits regulate the flow of traffic and the number of visitors in the King Range Wilderness. The quota system is based on each entry date and therefore permitees MUST enter on the start date printed on permit. From the date of entry, permittees can camp within the King Range NCA for up to 14 days per calendar year. Entry dates cannot be changed once permits are finalized and purchased, however the trip length, itinerary, and group size can be edited until permit is printed. 

Three people are allowed on each permit. Each person is allowed only one permit at any one time. For instance, a person could obtain a permit to hike in February, and upon return from trip can obtain another permit for May. If your group is more than 3 people, you will need an additional permit and a separate permittee to obtain them. 

Permitees are responsible to educate thier guests on all rules, regulations and safety concerns. This is often where groups fall short in following rules. Please take ample time to educate everyone in your group.

Organized and Commercial groups must contact the King Range Project Office at (707) 986-5400 or BLM_CA_Web_KR@blm.gov to reserve the Wilderness Permit & Special Recreation Permit in lieu of purchasing the Wilderness Permit via Recreation.gov. 

Winter Weather & Ocean Advisory: Winter storms & waves in the King Range NCA can make portions or all of the Lost Coast Trail dangerous and even impossible to traverse, regardless of tidal level. Additionally, heavy rains may cause downed trees or landslides along upland trails. Heavy rains may cause stream crossings to become hazardous and may impede travel. We at BLM recommend that you do not cross creeks that are above your knee. Be patient. Wait for water level to subside. Please contact the King Range Project Office at (707) 986-5400 or the Arcata Field Office at (707) 825-2300 for updates on current conditions and check The National Weather Service (http://www.weather.gov/eka/) for current coastal conditions.
description.need_to_know_pdf:
King Range Wilderness Rules and Regulations

The permittee must ensure that all trip participants abide by the rules, regulations, and Leave No Trace principles

Cell phone reception is spotty at best. The King Range Wilderness and the ocean are unforgiving. Plan ahead, prepare, and know the current hazards. Rescues are dangerous for all involved -- assume self-rescue is your only option.

All group members must abide by the following:

Rules and Regulations Campfires

  • Comply with all current fire restrictions.

  • Use only existing fire rings, or Leave No Trace techniques.

  • Clear all driftwood, dry grass and other flammable material away from the fire.

  • Use only dead and downed wood that you can easily break by hand.

  • Keep fires small and a person in attendance at all times. Extinguish fire with water (not sand), soak and stir until coals are cool to the touch.

Bear-Proof Food Storage

  • Each person must use an approved hard-sided bear-resistant food storage container. When not present, all food, toiletries, trash, dog food, and other scented items must be secured in the container.

Human Waste Disposal

  • When hiking and camping along the beach, bury all human waste in the wet sand below the high tide line.

  • On all other trails dig a 6-8' deep hole at least 200 feet (70 paces) from water, trails, and campsites.

  • Always completely bury your human waste and cover with soil. Bury or pack out all toilet paper.

King Range Wilderness Ethics

  • Do not add to existing or build new driftwood structures.

  • Pack out what you pack in.

  • Do not burn trash such as tin foil, glass, cans, or plastic.

  • Respect wildlife -- do not approach animals and keep pets on leash or under voice control at all times.

  • Respect other people's desire for solitude.
description.need_to_know_permit:
• ALERT: Backpackers on the Lost Coast Trail may face unsafe tide conditions at any time during the year. There are three sections that are impassible when the tide is over 3 feet. Weather, wind, swells, and other events may also affect the tide levels. Unfortunately, each year, hikers are swept out to sea, often due to poor planning.  
  • It's your duty to research and understand these dangers and ensure each person on your permit is aware of these safety concerns (see planning resources on BLM King Range website at https://www.blm.gov/programs/national-conservation-lands/california/king-range-national-conservation-area).
  • Prior to purchasing your permit, learn about the impassable sections and make sure they are passable on your dates. Each year, some people purchase permits and are unable to pass on those dates and end up cancelling their trip.

Learn more about the rules, regulations, and current conditions for King Range Wilderness. 

  • Visitors should be aware that wilderness permits are required year-round for overnight camping within the wilderness area (including the Lost Coast Trail). 
  • Hard-sided bear canisters are required; find detailed information and rental locations. 
  • Deposit solid human waste in holes dug 6 to 8 inches deep at least 200 feet (70 paces) from water, camp, and trails. Along the Lost Coast Trail, dig your hole in the intertidal zone (wet sand near the ocean). 
  • Be prepared for changing weather conditions. Storms can quickly make creeks impassable. Some sections of the Lost Coast Trail are impassable during high tide; consult a tide table when trip planning. Never turn your back on the ocean. 
  • Campfire permits are required when campfires are allowed. You must have a CalFire Campfire permit along with this Wilderness Permit in order to be in compliance. Obtain the campfire permit online: https://www.readyforwildfire.org/permits/campfire-permit/. Campfires are prohibited approximately mid-June through mid-October. Some years, extreme fire weather will also prohibit campstoves, campfires, or any open flame, usually in August to the end of fire season.  
  • DRONES are not allowed in the King Range Wilderness. Commercial filming on the ground is allowed with permit only. 

Call the King Range Project Office for current conditions. 

  • Review the King Range Wilderness Checklist to prepare for your trip. 
  • Review the seven principles of Leave No Trace. 
  • Visitors hiking the Lost Coast Trail one-way will either need to bring an extra vehicle to drop-off at the finishing trailhead, or contact an authorized shuttle provider. These shuttles have proper licensing, insurance, and certifications needed to obtain a Special Use permit for shuttle driving and commercial use in the King Range. Any offers not on this list do not have the proper permit for shuttle services in the King Range NCA.
  • All roads in the King Range NCA are narrow, steep, winding and there are road and sections of roads that are gravel and/or have many potholes. Allow plenty of time between destinations. Find more information and travel times. 
  • Learn more about the King Range National Conservation Area. 
  • Plan ahead for winter trips. Winter storms and waves in the King Range can make portions or all of the Lost Coast Trail dangerous and even impossible to traverse, regardless of tidal level. Additionally, heavy rains may cause downed trees or landslides along upland trails and roads.  

Printing Your Reserved Permit 

You may print your permit as early as seven days before your reservation date. The permit must be carried by the permit holder. Permittee is responsible to educate all in their hiking party on these rules and stipulations. Permits are non-transferrable. Once your permit has been printed, you cannot make changes to the permit. If you decide to cancel, please do so on your recreation.gov account in order to place them back in the quota system. 

For more information or help planning your itinerary, call the King Range Project Office at (707) 986-5400.
description.no_show_policy: Please cancel your permit if you end up not using it so that others may enjoy the wilderness.
description.quota_details:
In order to provide for solitude and protect the fragile wilderness the quota system controls the number of permits that can be issued at one time. Individual Wilderness Permits are restricted to a size of 3 people and each person can have one active permit at a time. Organized (scouts, meet-up groups, classes, etc.) or commercial groups (outfitters, non-profit groups, etc.) may have up to 15 people and must have a Special Recreation Permit (SRP) in addition to the Wilderness Permit, both must be obtained from the King Range Project Office.  

Trailhead entrees for all visitors camping overnight is limited to:  

  • 60 persons per day May 15 through September 15 (15 starts per day for SRP groups)
  • 30 persons per day September 16 through May 14 
  • All permits not sold to SRP groups during high peak season will be placed back into general sales for anyone to purchase on the first day of each month, starting May 1.
description.season_information:
A permit quota system has been established to ensure visitors a wilderness experience, free of large crowds on the trails. Permits are required year-round for overnight camping in the King Range Wilderness. No permit is required for day-use. The permit size is limited to 3 persons per permit. The start date of the permit is strictly monitored and visitors are required to begin their trip on the permitted start date, no exceptions. Early or late starts will not be authorized. Permit availability is based on the start date only. Permits are non-transferrable.

  • The block of permits for each calendar year are released the preceding year on October 1 (e.g., 2022 permits are available October 1, 2021) 
  • 1 active permit allowed per customer 
  • It's imperative that visitors to the Lost Coast Trail check the tides PRIOR to purchasing a permit, as some days the Lost Coast Trail is not passable due to tide levels. See "Tide Safety Guide" on the BLM King Range website.
description.tertiary_page:
King Range Wilderness Permits (Lost Coast)

Camp Zone Descriptions and Map

The camp zone descriptions and map are intended to assist in planning your overnight backcountry trip into the King Range Wilderness.

For more information we suggest contacting the King Range Project Office at (707) 986-5400.

Camp Zone Area Descriptions:

• North Coast: Lost Coast Trail from the Mattole Trailhead to Cooskie Creek

• Uplands North: King Range Wilderness above the Lost Coast Trail from Mattole Trailhead to the north end of Big Flat

• Randall-Spanish-Big Creeks: Lost Coast Trail from Randall Creek to the north end of Big Flat

• Big Flat/Miller Flat: Lost Coast Trail on the north and south side of Big Flat Creek

• Buck and Shipman Creeks: Lost Coast Trail from the south end of Miller Flat to approximately 0.5 mile south of Buck Creek

• Uplands South: King Range Wilderness above the Lost Coast Trail from the north end of Big Flat to Lightning Trailhead and extending south to Shelter Cove

• South Coast: One mile north of Gitchell Creek to Black Sands Beach Trailhead

• Chemise Mountain: King Range Wilderness south of Shelter Cove; Hidden Valley Trailhead to Sinkyone Wilderness State Park
description.video_title: Visitor Tips for the Lost Coast Trail
description.video_transcript:
Welcome to the Lost Coast Trail in the King Range National Conservation Area. This spectacular area of rugged mountains and seascapes has no bathrooms or amenities. It is up to you to responsibly manage your waste.

Steep mountains make it impossible to find a responsible place to dispose of human waste, except towards the ocean.

Bury human waste on the beach to avoid polluting drinking water sources and keep camp areas clean.

Dig a 6-8” inch hole in wet sand in the intertidal zone. Go as close to the ocean as safely possible. Completely cover your deposit to maximize decomposition and to prevent unsightly encounters by other visitors. The ocean will breakdown the waste upon the next high tide.

Although exposed, other hikers will give you your space if they see you crouching from a distance. The natural rise and fall of the sand will provide privacy from other hikers.

Please remember to pack out toilet paper and feminine hygiene products.

When you are on upland trails, go at least 70 steps from campsites, trails, and water.

Enjoy your visit and thank you for ensuring we keep this pristine area clean.

Video produced by the King Range National Conservation Area.

113414.description: Visitors planning to camp overnight in the King Range Wilderness will be asked to provide a tentative itinerary; including number of days in the wilderness, entrance trailhead, exit trailhead, and backcountry camp zones. To assist in planning an overnight trip into the King Range Wilderness, take time to review the trailhead descriptions and directions, as well as the camp zone map and zone descriptions. The start date of the permit is strictly monitored and visitors are required to begin their trip on the permitted start date. Early or late starts will not be authorized. Permit availability is based on the start date only.

description_map.need_to_know:
• Permits are required year-round for overnight camping in the King Range Wilderness. 
  • No permit is required for day-use.
